•  Establish a therapeutic nurse-patient relationship
•  Use effective verbal and nonverbal communication
techniques
•  Collect health history data
•  Modify assessment techniques to reflect variations across
the life span and cultural variations
•  Document actions and observations
•  Recognize and report significant deviations from norms
“‘Sickness’ is what is happening to the patient. Listen to them.”
The profession of nursing is defined by the American Nurses Association
as “the protection, promotion, and optimization of health and abilities,
prevention of illness and injury, facilitation of healing, alleviation of
advocacy in the care of individuals, families, groups, communities, and
populations.”
Simply put, nurses treat human responses to health
problems and/or life processes. Nurses look at each person holistically,
including emotional, spiritual, psychosocial, and physical health needs.
They also consider problems and issues that the person experiences as a
part of a family and a community. To collect detailed information about a
patient’s human response to illness and life processes, nurses perform a
health history. A health history is part of the Assessment phase of the
nursing process. It consists of using directed, focused interview questions
and open-ended questions to obtain symptoms and perceptions from the
patient about their illnesses, functioning, and life processes. While
obtaining a health history, the nurse is also simultaneously performing a
general survey. Visit the “General Survey Assessment” chapter more
information.
Obtaining a patient’s health history is a component of the Assessment
phase of the nursing process. Information obtained while performing a
health history is called subjective data. Subjective data is information
obtained from the patient and/or family members and can provide
important cues about functioning and unmet needs requiring assistance.
Subjective data is considered a symptom because it is something the
patient reports. When documenting subjective data in a progress note, it
should be included in quotation marks and start with verbiage such as,
“The patient reports…” or “The patient’s wife states…” An example of
subjective data is when the patient reports, “I feel dizzy.”
A patient is considered the primary source of subjective data. Secondary
sources of data include information from the patient’s chart, family
members, or other health care team members. Patients are oftenaccompanied by their care partners. Care partners are family and friends
who are involved in helping to care for the patient. For example, parents
are care partners for children; spouses are often care partners for each
other, and adult children are often care partners for their aging parents.
When obtaining a health history, care partners may contribute important
information related to the health and needs of the patient. If data is
gathered from someone other than the patient, the nurse should
document where the information is obtained.
Objective data is information observed through your senses of hearing,
sight, smell, and touch while assessing the patient. Objective data is
obtained during the physical examination component of the assessment
process. Examples of objective data are vital signs, physical examination
findings, and laboratory results. An example of objective data is recording
a blood pressure reading of 140/86. Subjective data and objective data are
often recorded together during an assessment. For example, the
symptom the patient reports,  “I feel itchy all over,” is documented in
association with the sign of an observed raised red rash located on the
upper back and chest.
Addressing Barriers and Adapting CommunicationIt is vital to establish rapport with a patient before asking questions about
sensitive topics to obtain accurate data regarding the mental, emotional,
and spiritual aspects of a patient’s condition. When interviewing a patient,
also consider the patient’s developmental status and level of
understanding. Ask one question at a time and allow adequate time for
the patient to respond. If the patient does not provide an answer even
with additional time, try rephrasing the question in a different way for
improved understanding.
If any barriers to communication exist, adapt your communication to that
patient’s specific needs. For more information about potential
communication barriers and strategies for adapting communication, visitthe “Communication” chapter in Open RN Nursing Fundamentals.
It is important to conduct a health history in a culturally safe manner.
Cultural safety refers to the creation of safe spaces for patients to interact
with health professionals without judgment or discrimination. Focus on
factors related to a person’s cultural background that may influence their
health status. It is helpful to use an open-ended question to allow the
patient to share what they believe to be important. For example, ask “I am
interested in your cultural background as it relates to your health. Can you
share with me what is important to know about your cultural background
as part of your health care?”
If a patient’s primary language is not English, it is important to obtain a
medical translator, as needed, prior to initiating the health history. The
patient’s family member or care partner should not interpret for the
patient. The patient may not want their care partner to be aware of their
health problems or their care partner may not be familiar with correct
medical terminology that can result in miscommunication.
After identifying the reason why the patient is seeking health care,
additional focused questions are used to obtain detailed information
about this concern. The mnemonic PQRSTU is often used to ask the
for an image ofpatient questions in an organized fashion. See Figure 2.1
PQRSTU.
used to assess many other symptoms. See Table 2.5b for suggested focus
questions for pain and other symptoms using the PQRSTU mnemonic.
Table 2.5b Sample PQRSTU Focused Questions for Pain and Other
Symptoms
While interviewing a patient about their chief complaint, use open-ended
questions to allow the patient to elaborate on information that further
improves your understanding of their health concerns. If their answers do
not seem to align, continue to ask focused questions to clarify information.
For example, if a patient states that “the pain is tolerable” but also rates
the pain as a “7” on a 0-10 pain scale, these answers do not align, and the
nurse should continue to use follow-up questions using the PQRSTUframework. For example, upon further questioning the patient explains
they rate the pain as a “7” in their knee when participating in physical
therapy exercises, but currently feels the pain is tolerable while resting in
bed. This additional information will help the nurse customize
interventions for effective treatment.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: The nutritional category includes, but is not limited to, food and fluid

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: intake, usual diet, financial ability to purchase food, time and knowledge

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: to prepare meals, and appetite. This is also an opportune time to engage

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: in health promotion discussions about healthy eating. Be aware of signs

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: for malnutrition and obesity, especially if rapid and excessive weight loss

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: or weight gain have occurred.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Life Span Considerations

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: When assessing nutritional status, the types of questions asked and the

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: level of detail depend on the developmental age and health of the patient.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Family members may also provide important information.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: •  Infants: Ask parents about using breast milk or formula, amount,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: frequency, supplements, problems, and introductions of new foods.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: •  Pregnant women: Include questions about the presence of nausea

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: and vomiting and intake of folic acid, iron, omega-3 fatty acids, vitamin

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: D, and calcium.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: •  Older adults or patients with disabling illnesses: Inquire about the

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: ability to purchase and cook their food, decreased sense of taste,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: ability to chew or swallow foods, loss of appetite, and enough fiber and

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: nutrients.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Elimination refers to the removal of waste products through the urine and

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: stool. Health care professionals refer to urinating as voiding and stool

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: elimination as having a bowel movement. Familiar terminology may need

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: to be used with patients, such as “pee” and “poop.”  Constipation

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: commonly occurs in hospitalized patients, so it is important to assess the

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: date of their last bowel movement and monitor the frequency, color, and

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: consistency of their stool. Assess urine concentration, frequency, and odor,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: especially if concerned about urinary tract infection, incontinence, or

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: infection. Findings that require further investigation include dysuria (pain

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: or difficulty upon urination), blood in the stool, melena (black, tarry stool),

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: constipation, diarrhea, or excessive laxative use.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Life Span Considerations

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: When assessing elimination, the types of questions asked and the level of

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: detail depends on the developmental age and health of the patient.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Toddlers: Ask parents or guardians about toilet training. Toilet training

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: takes several months, occurs in several stages, and varies from child to

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: child. It is influenced by culture and depends on physical and emotional

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: readiness, but most children are toilet trained between 18 months and

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: three years.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Older Adults: Constipation and incontinence are common symptoms

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: associated with aging. Additional focused questions may be required to

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: further assess these issues.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Mobility refers to a patient’s ability to move around (e.g., sit up, sit down,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: stand up, walk). Activity and exercise refer to informal and/or formal

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: activity (e.g., walking, swimming, yoga, strength training). In addition to

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: assessing the amount of exercise, it is also important to assess activity

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: because some people may not engage in exercise but have an active

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: lifestyle (e.g., walk to school or work in a physically demanding job).

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Findings that require further investigation include insufficient aerobic

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: exercise and identified risks for falls.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Life Span Considerations

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Mobility and activity depend on developmental age and a patient’s health

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: and illness status. With infants, it is important to assess their ability to

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: meet specific developmental milestones at each well-baby visit. Mobility

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: can become problematic for patients who are ill or are aging and can

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: result in self-care deficits. Thus, it is important to assess how a patient’s

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: mobility is affecting their ability to perform ADLs and IADLs.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: The sleep and rest category refers to a patient’s pattern of rest and sleep

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: and any associated routines or sleeping medications used. Although it

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: varies for different people and their life circumstances, obtaining eight

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: hours of sleep every night is a general guideline. Findings that require

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: further investigation include disruptive sleep patterns and reliance on

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: sleeping pills or other sedative medications.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Life Span Considerations

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Older Adults: Disruption in sleep patterns can be especially troublesome

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: for older adults. Assessing sleep patterns and routines will contribute to

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: collaborative interventions for improved rest.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: The cognitive and perceptual category focuses on a person’s ability to

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: collect information from the environment and use it in reasoning and

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: other thought processes. This category includes the following:

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: •  Adequacy of vision, hearing, taste, touch, feeling, and smell

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: •  Any assistive devices used

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: •  Pain level and pain management

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: •  Cognitive functional abilities, such as orientation, memory, reasoning,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: judgment, and decision-making

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: If a patient is experiencing pain, it is important to perform an in-depthassessment using the PQRSTU method described in the “Reason for

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Seeking Health Care” section of this chapter. It is also helpful to use

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: evidence-based assessment tools when assessing pain, especially for

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: patients who are unable to verbally describe the severity of their pain. See

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Figure 2.4

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: for an image of the Wong-Baker FACES tool that is commonly

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: used in health care.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Life Span Considerations

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Older Adults: Older adults are especially at risk for problems in the

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: cognitive and perceptual category. Be alert for cues that suggest deficits

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: are occurring that have not been previously diagnosed.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: established with family, friends, and the broader community. Roles often

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: define our identity. For example, a patient may describe themselves as a

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: “mother of an 8 year old.” This category focuses on roles and relationships

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: that may be influenced by health-related factors or may offer support

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: during illness.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Findings that require further investigation include

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: indications that a patient does not have any meaningful relationships or

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: has “negative” or abusive relationships in their lives.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Life Span Considerations

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Be sensitive to cues when assessing individuals with any of the following

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: characteristics: isolation from family and friends during crisis, language

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: barriers, loss of a significant person or pet, loss of job, significant home

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: care needs, prolonged caregiving, history of abuse, history of substance

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: abuse, or homelessness.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Sexuality and sexual relations are an aspect of health that can be affected

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: by illness, aging, and medication. This category includes a person’s gender

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: identity and sexual orientation, as well as reproductive issues. It involves a

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: combination of emotional connection, physical companionship (holding

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: hands, hugging, kissing) and sexual activity that impact one’s feeling of

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: health.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: The Joint Commission has defined terms to use when caring for diverse

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: patients. Gender identity is a person’s basic sense of being male, female,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: or other gender.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Gender expression are characteristics in appearance,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: personality, and behavior that are culturally defined as masculine or

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: an individual’s physical and/or emotional attraction to the same and/or

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: opposite gender.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: LGBT is an acronym standing for the lesbian, gay,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: bisexual, and transgender population. It is an umbrella term that generally

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: refers to a group of people who are diverse in gender identity and sexual

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: orientation. It is important to provide a safe environment to discuss health

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: issues because the LGBT population experiences higher rates of smoking,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: alcohol use, substance abuse, HIV and other STD infections, anxiety,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: depression, suicidal ideation and attempts, and eating disorders as a result

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: of stigma and marginalization.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Life Span Considerations

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Although sexuality is frequently portrayed in the media, individuals often

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: consider these topics as private subjects. Use sensitivity when discussing

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: these topics with different age groups across cultural beliefs while

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: maintaining professional boundaries.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Individuals experience stress that can lead to dysfunction if not managed

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: in a healthy manner. Throughout life, healthy and unhealthy coping

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: strategies are learned. Coping strategies are behaviors used to manage

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: anxiety. Effective strategies control anxiety and lead to problem solving

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: but ineffective strategies can lead to abuse of food, tobacco, alcohol, or

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: drugs.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Nurses teach and reinforce effective coping strategies.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Substance Use and Abuse

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Alcohol, tobacco products, marijuana, and drugs are often used as

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: ineffective coping strategies. It is important to use a nonjudgmental

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: approach when assessing a patient’s use of substances so they do not feel

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: stigmatized. Substance abuse can affect people of all ages. Make a

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: distinction between use and abuse as you assess frequency of use and

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: patterns of behavior. Substance abuse often causes disruption in everyday

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: function (e.g., loss of employment, deterioration of relationships, or

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: precarious living circumstances) because of dependence on a substance.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Action is needed if patients indicate that they have a problem with

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: substance use or show signs of dependence, addiction, or binge

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: drinking.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Life Span Considerations

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Some individuals are at increased risk for problems with coping strategies

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: and stress management. Be sensitive to cues when assessing individuals

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: with characteristics such as uncertainty in medical diagnosis or prognosis,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: financial problems, marital problems, poor job fit, or few close friends and

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: family members.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: This category includes values and beliefs that guide decisions about

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: health care and can also provide strength and comfort to individuals. It is

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: common for a person’s spirituality and values to be influenced by religious

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: faith. A value is an accepted principle or standard of an individual or

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: group. A belief is something accepted as true with a sense of certainty.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Spirituality is a way of living that comes from a set of values and beliefs

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: that are important to a person. The Joint Commission asks health care

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: professionals to respect patients’ cultural and personal values, beliefs, and

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: preferences and accommodate patients’ rights to religious and other

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: spiritual services.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: When performing an assessment, use open-ended

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: questions to allow the patient to share values and beliefs they believe are

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: important. For example, ask, “I am interested in your spiritual and religious

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: beliefs and how they relate to your health. Can you share with me any

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: spiritual beliefs or religious practices that are important to you during your

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: stay?”

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: The focus of this category is on the subjective thoughts, feelings, and

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: attitudes of a patient about themself. Self-concept refers to all the

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: knowledge a person has about themself that makes up who they are (i.e.,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: their identity). Self-esteem refers to a person’s self-evaluation of these

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: items as being worthy or unworthy. Body image is a mental picture of

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: one’s body related to appearance and function. It is best to assess these

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: items toward the end of the interview because you will have already

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: collected data that contributes to an understanding of the patient’s self-

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: concept. Factors that influence a patient’s self-concept vary from person

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: to person and include elements of life they value, such as talents,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: education, accomplishments, family, friends, career, financial status,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: spirituality, and religion.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: The self-perception and self-concept category

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: also focuses on feelings and mood states such as happiness, anxiety, hope,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: power, anger, fear, depression, and control.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Life Span Considerations

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Some individuals are at risk for problems with self-perception and self-

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: concept. Be sensitive to cues when assessing individuals with

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: characteristics such as uncertainty regarding a medical diagnosis or

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: surgery, significant personal loss, history of abuse or neglect, loss of body

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: part or function, or history of substance abuse.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Violence and Trauma

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: There are many types of violence that a person may experience, including

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: neglect or physical, emotional, mental, sexual, or financial abuse. You are

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: well as suspected cases of elder abuse. At any time, if you or the patient is

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: in immediate danger, follow agency policy and procedure.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Trauma results from violence or other distressing events in a life.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Collaborative intervention with the patient is required when violence and

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: trauma are identified. People respond in different ways to trauma. It is

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: important to use a trauma-informed approach when caring for patients

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: who have experienced trauma. For example, a patient may respond to the

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: traumatic situation in a way that seems unfitting (such as with laughter,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: ambivalence, or denial). This does not mean the patient is lying but can be

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: a symptom of trauma. To reduce the effects of trauma, it is important to

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: implement collaborative interventions to support patients who have

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: experienced trauma.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Loss of Body Part

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: A person can have negative feelings or perceptions about the

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: characteristics, function, or limits of a body part as a result of a medical

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: condition, surgery, trauma, or mental condition. Pay attention to cues,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: such as neglect of a body part or negative comments about a body part,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: and use open-ended questions to obtain additional information.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Mental Health

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Mental health is frequently underscreened and unaddressed in health

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: care. The mental health of all patients should be assessed, even if they

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: changes in condition are quickly noticed and treatment implemented.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Mental health includes emotional and psychological symptoms that can

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: affect a patient’s day-to-day ability to function. The World Health

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Organization (2014) defines mental health as “a state of well-being in

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: which every individual realizes their own potential, can cope with normal

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: stresses of life, can work productively and fruitfully, and is able to make a

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: contribution to their community.”

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Mental illness includes conditions

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: diagnosed by a health care provider, such as depression, anxiety,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: addiction, schizophrenia, post-traumatic stress disorder, and others.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Mental illness can disrupt everyday functioning and affect a person’s

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: employment, education, and relationships.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: It is helpful to begin this component of a mental health assessment with a

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: statement such as, “Mental health is an important part of our lives, so I ask

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: all patients about their mental health and any concerns or questions they

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: may have.”

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Be attentive of critical findings that require intervention. For

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: example, if a patient talks about feeling hopeless or depressed, it is

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: important to screen for suicidal thinking. Begin with an open-ended

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: question, such as, “Have you ever felt like hurting yourself?” If the patient

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: responds with a “Yes,” then progress with specific questions that assess

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: the immediacy and the intensity of the feelings. For example, you may say,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: “Tell me more about that feeling. Have you been thinking about hurting

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: yourself today? Have you put together a plan to hurt yourself?” When

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: assessing for suicidal thinking, be aware that a patient most at risk is

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: someone who has a specific plan about self-harm and can specify how

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: and when they will do it. They are particularly at risk if planning self-harm

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: within the next 48 hours. The age of the patient is not a factor in this

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: determination of risk. If you believe the patient is at high risk, do not leave

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: the patient alone. Collaborate with them regarding an immediate plan for

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: emergency care.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Health perception-health management is an umbrella term

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: encompassing all of the categories described above, as well as

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: environmental health.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Environmental Health

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Environmental health refers to the safety of a patient’s physical

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: environment, also called a social determinant of health. Examples of

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: environmental health include, but are not limited to, exposure to violence

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: in the home or community; air pollution; and availability of grocery stores,

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: health care providers, and public transportation. Findings that require

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: further investigation include a patient living in unsafe environments.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: See Table 2.8 for sample focused questions for all categories related to

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: functional health.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Table 2.8 Focused Interview Questions for Functional Health Categories

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Begin this section by saying, “I would like to ask you some questions

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: about factors that affect your ability to function in your day-to-day life.

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: Feel free to share any health concerns that come to mind during this

Section: 2.8 Functional Health and Activities of Daily Living
Text: discussion.”

Section: 2.11 Checklist for Obtaining a Health History

Section: 2.11 Checklist for Obtaining a Health History
Text: 4.  Address patient needs (pain, toileting, glasses/hearing aids) prior to

Section: 2.11 Checklist for Obtaining a Health History
Text: starting. Note if the patient has signs of distress such as difficulty

Section: 2.11 Checklist for Obtaining a Health History
Text: breathing or chest pain. If signs are present, defer the health history

Section: 2.11 Checklist for Obtaining a Health History
Text: and obtain emergency assistance per agency policy.

Section: 2.11 Checklist for Obtaining a Health History
Text: 5.  Complete a health history interview, including the following

Section: 2.11 Checklist for Obtaining a Health History
Text: components per your instructor’s instructions:

Section: 2.11 Checklist for Obtaining a Health History
Text: ◦  Demographic and Biological Data◦  Reason for Seeking Health Care◦  Current and Past Medical History◦  Family History◦  Functional Health◦  Review of Body Systems

Section: 2.11 Checklist for Obtaining a Health History
Text: 6.  Ensure five safety measures before leaving the room:

Section: 2.11 Checklist for Obtaining a Health History
Text: ◦  CALL LIGHT: Within reach◦  BED: Low and locked (in lowest position and brakes on)◦  SIDE RAILS: Secured◦  TABLE: Within reach◦  ROOM: Risk-free for falls (scan room and clear any obstacles)

Section: 2.11 Checklist for Obtaining a Health History
Text: 7.  Document the health history findings and report any concerns

•  Accurately measure and document blood pressure using
American Heart Association standards
•  Adapt the procedure to reflect variations across the life
span
•  Recognize and report significant deviations from blood
pressure norms
The accurate measurement of blood pressure is important for ensuring
patient safety and optimizing body system function. Blood pressure
measurements are used by health care providers to make important
decisions about a patient’s care. Blood pressure measurements help
providers make decisions about whether a patient needs fluids or
prescription medications. It is crucial to follow the proper steps to obtain a
patient’s blood pressure to ensure the care team has accurate data to helpmake health care decisions and determine a plan of care.
A blood pressure reading is the measurement of the force of blood against
the walls of the arteries as the heart pumps blood through the body. It is
reported in millimeters of mercury (mmHg). This pressure changes in the
arteries when the heart is contracting compared to when it is resting and
filling with blood. Blood pressure is typically expressed as the reflection of
two numbers, systolic pressure and diastolic pressure. The systolic blood
pressure is the maximum pressure on the arteries during systole, the
phase of the heartbeat when the ventricles contract. Systole causes the
ejection of blood out of the ventricles and into the aorta and pulmonary
arteries. The diastolic blood pressure is the resting pressure on the
arteries during diastole, the phase between each contraction of the heart
when the ventricles are filling with blood.
Blood pressure measurements are obtained using a stethoscope and a
sphygmomanometer, also called a blood pressure cuff. To obtain a
manual blood pressure reading, the blood pressure cuff is placed around a
patient’s extremity, and a stethoscope is placed over an artery. For most
blood pressure readings, the cuff is usually placed around the upper arm,
and the stethoscope is placed over the brachial artery. The cuff is inflated
deflated slowly. The American Heart Association (AHA) recommends that
the blood pressure cuff be inflated at least 30 mmHg above the point at
which the radial pulse is no longer palpable. The first appearance of
sounds, called Korotkoff sounds, are noted as the systolic blood pressure
reading. Korotkoff sounds are named after Dr. Korotkoff, who first
discovered the audible sounds of blood pressure when the arm is
constricted.Korotkoff sounds disappear. The last Korotkoff sounds reflect the diastolic
2 The blood pressure cuff continues to be deflated until
blood pressure reading.more than 2-3 mmHg per second to ensure that the absence of pulse is
3 It is important to deflate the cuff slowly at no
noted promptly and that the reading is accurate. Blood pressure readings
are documented as systolic blood pressure/diastolic pressure, for example,
Abnormal blood pressure readings can signify an area of concern and a
need for intervention. Normal adult blood pressure is less than 120/80
mmHg. Hypertension is the medical term for elevated blood pressure
readings of 130/80 mmHg or higher. See Table 4.2 for blood pressure
categories according to the 2017 American College of Cardiology and
American Heart Association Blood Pressure Guidelines.
Prior to
diagnosing a person with hypertension, the health care provider will
calculate an average blood pressure based on two or more blood pressure
readings obtained on two or more occasions.
Hypotension is the medical term for low blood pressure readings less than
90/60 mmHg.
Hypotension can be caused by dehydration, bleeding,
can be of significant concern because of the potential lack of perfusion to
critical organs when blood pressures are low. Orthostatic hypotension is a
drop in blood pressure that occurs when moving from a lying down
(supine) or seated position to a standing (upright) position. When
measuring blood pressure, orthostatic hypotension is defined as a
decrease in blood pressure by at least 20 mmHg systolic or 10 mmHg
diastolic within three minutes of standing. When a person stands, gravity
moves blood from the upper body to the lower limbs. As a result, there is a
temporary reduction in the amount of blood in the upper body for the
heart to pump, which decreases blood pressure. Normally, the body
quickly counteracts the force of gravity and maintains stable blood
pressure and blood flow. In most people, this transient drop in blood
pressure goes unnoticed. However, some patients with orthostatic
hypotension can experience light-headedness, dizziness, or fainting.  This
is a significant safety concern because of the increased risk of falls and
injury, particularly in older adults.
Table 4.2 Blood Pressure Categories
View Ahmend Alzawi’s Korotkoff Sounds Video on
YouTube
Manual Blood Pressure
A sphygmomanometer, commonly called a blood pressure cuff, is used to
measure blood pressure while Korotkoff sounds are auscultated using a
for an image of a sphygmomanometer.stethoscope. See Figure 3.1
There are various sizes of blood pressure cuffs. It is crucial to select the
appropriate size for the patient to obtain an accurate reading. An
undersized cuff will cause an artificially high blood pressure reading, and
an oversized cuff will produce an artificially low reading. See Figure 3.2
for
an image of various sizes of blood pressure cuffs ranging in size for a large
The width of the cuff should be 40% of the person’s arm circumference,
and the length of the cuff’s bladder should be 80–100% of the person’s
arm circumference. Keep in mind that only about half of the blood
pressure cuff is the bladder and the other half is cloth with a hook and
loop fastener to secure it around the arm.
View Ryerson University’s Accurate Blood Pressure CuffSizing Video on YouTube
Automatic Blood Pressure Equipment
Automatic blood pressure monitors are often used in health care settings
to efficiently measure blood pressure for multiple patients or to repeatedly
measure a single patient’s blood pressure at a specific frequency such as
every 15 minutes. See Figure 3.3
for an image of an automatic blood
pressure monitor. To use an automatic blood pressure monitor,
appropriately position the patient and place the correctly sized blood
pressure cuff on their bare arm or other extremity. Press the start button
on the monitor. The cuff will automatically inflate and then deflate at a
rate of 2 mmHg per second. The monitor digitally displays the blood
pressure reading when done. If the blood pressure reading is unexpected,
it is important to follow up by obtaining a reading using a manual blood
pressure cuff. Additionally, automatic blood pressure monitors should not
be used if the patient has a rapid or irregular heart rhythm, such as atrial
fibrillation, or has tremors as it may lead to an inaccurate reading.
Before taking a person’s blood pressure, it is important to determine if
they have a history of elevated blood pressure or if they are taking any
blood pressure medication. It is helpful to establish a baseline by asking
their usual blood pressure reading or reviewing previous records in their
chart. It is also important to determine if there are any arm restrictions
such as those due to a fistula, mastectomy, stroke, or IV line before
measuring blood pressure. See Table 3.3a for sample interview questions
associated with the subjective assessment of blood pressure.
Table 3.3a Interview Questions for Subjective Assessment of Blood
Pressure
Inspection
Before obtaining a blood pressure reading, it is important to inspect and
consider conditions that would prevent the use of a blood pressure cuff,
such as a history of clots or presence of current clots, lymphedema,
wounds, a fistula, or current IV access lines. If these conditions exist, obtain
the blood pressure in an alternative extremity.
Life Span Considerations
Children
Blood pressure measurement is not routinely performed on children
under the age of 3 unless there are cardiac concerns.
Older Adults
Blood pressure measurements are sometimes difficult to hear in older
adults. For patients who are clinically stable and Korotkoff sound
auscultation is difficult, doppler auscultation may be helpful.
Clinical Tips
Blood pressure assessment should be completed after the patient has
rested for a minimum of five minutes. If the patient has ingested caffeine
should be documented with the reading.
There are times when it is difficult to auscultate Korotkoff sounds. As a
result, the care team must decide what alternate measures could be
performed to obtain accurate blood pressure results. For patients who are
critically ill or hemodynamically unstable, an arterial line may be placed
directly into an artery to measure blood pressure. This is an invasive
procedure and is not used for routine monitoring.
See Table 3.3b for a comparison of expected versus unexpected findings
when assessing blood pressure.
Table 3.3b Expected Versus Unexpected Findings on Blood Pressure
Assessment
Blood pressure was 120/80 mmHg on the left arm with the patient in a
seated position using a manual cuff.
Blood pressure reading was collected with routine vital signs and noted
to be 160/95 in the right arm. Blood pressure was retaken in the left arm
after the patient rested for 5 minutes and was 154/93. Patient reports no
history of hypertension and no current blood pressure medications.
Patient denies dizziness, headache, visual changes, and light-
headedness. Dr. Smith was notified, and an order for furosemide 20 mg
was received.
Disclaimer: Always review and follow agency policy regarding this
specific skill.
1.  Gather supplies: blood pressure cuff and stethoscope. (Select an
appropriately sized cuff for the patient.)
◦  The width of the cuff should be 40% of the person’s arm
circumference, and the length of the cuff’s bladder should be
80–100% of the person’s arm circumference.
2.  Perform safety steps:
◦  Perform hand hygiene.◦  Check the room for transmission-based precautions.◦  Introduce yourself, your role, the purpose of your visit, and an
estimate of the time it will take.
◦  Confirm patient ID using two patient identifiers (e.g., name and
date of birth).
◦  Explain the process to the patient and ask if they have any
questions.
◦  Be organized and systematic.◦  Use appropriate listening and questioning skills.◦  Listen and attend to patient cues.◦  Ensure the patient’s privacy and dignity.◦  Assess ABCs.
3.  Cleanse the stethoscope and blood pressure cuff prior to placing it on
the patient’s skin.
4.  Place the patient in a relaxed reclining or sitting position. The patient
should be seated quietly for at least five minutes in a chair prior to
blood pressure measurement. Ask the patient which arm they prefer
to use. Be aware of conditions that contraindicate the use of an armfor blood pressure measurement, such as a previous mastectomy or
the presence of a fistula. During the procedure, both feet should be on
the floor and the arm should be supported at heart level.
◦  Adapt the procedure to life span considerations of the patient.
5.  Remove or rearrange clothing so the cuff and the stethoscope are on
bare skin.
6.  Center the bladder of the blood pressure cuff over the brachial artery
with the lower margin 1″ above the antecubital space. Fit the cuff
evenly and snugly. Palpate the brachial artery in the antecubital space.
7.  Locate the radial pulse.
8.  Inflate the cuff rapidly (while palpating the radial or brachial pulse) to
the level at which pulsations are no longer felt and inflate the cuff 30
mmHg above the palpated pressure or the patient’s usual blood
pressure.  Note the level and rapidly deflate the cuff; wait 30 seconds.
9.  With the eartips of the stethoscope placed downward and forward,
place the bell/diaphragm lightly on the brachial artery and rapidly
inflate the cuff to 30 points above where the brachial or radial pulse is
no longer felt.
10.  Deflate the cuff gradually at a constant rate by opening the valve on
the bulb (2-3 mm Hg/second) until the first Korotkoff sound is heard.
Note the systolic pressure.
11.  Continue to deflate the cuff slowly at 2 mm Hg/second. Note the point
at which Korotkoff sounds disappear completely as the diastolic
pressure.
12.  Deflate the cuff completely and remove the patient’s arm from the
cuff.
13.  Inform the patient of the blood pressure reading.
14.  Cleanse the stethoscope and blood pressure cuff.
15.  Perform proper hand hygiene.
16.  Ensure five safety measures before leaving the room:
◦  CALL LIGHT: Within reach◦  BED: Low and locked (in lowest position and brakes on)◦  SIDE RAIL: Secured◦  TABLE: Within reach◦  ROOM: Risk-free for falls (scan room and clear any obstacles)
17.  Document findings and report significant deviations from norms
according to agency policy.
